title: Tracking tropics | Expected to be tropical storm this week , potential Tropical Cyclone Five forms in Atlantic
message:
Potential Tropical Cyclone Five forms in Atlantic, expected to be tropical storm this weekNORT CAROLINA (WTVD) -- Potential Tropical Cyclone Five formed 900 miles east of St. Lucia on Sunday.
ABC11 Meteorologist Robert Johnson said the storm will move west and is expected to become a tropical storm by Monday.
The storm will likely become Tropical Storm Ernesto.
The storm comes days after Debby moved up the East Coast unleashing tornadoes and flooding in multiple states.
Hurricane Debby, which entered North Carolina as a tropical storm, weakened into a tropical depression, has moved out of the U.S. over the weekend.

title: Weather tracker : Storm Debby leaves power cuts and flooding in its wake
message:
Meanwhile, a tropical disturbance in the Atlantic is likely to develop into a named storm within days Storm Debby, which initially struck Florida as a hurricane, caused widespread destruction as it moved up the east coast, leaving many without power and dealing with severe flooding.
The storm... read full story

title: Atlantic front forming into tropical storm headed toward U . S . Virgin Islands
message:
An Atlantic front is threatening to strengthen into a storm as it heads toward various Caribbean islands.
The potential cyclone was gaining strength rapidly enough that the center said it would most likely be a named tropical storm by the end of Monday.
If so, the name Ernesto is in line for the next Atlantic storm.
It would be the fifth named storm of the Atlantic hurricane season so far, as indicated by its temporary name.
It says near-record warmth in the tropical Atlantic is providing ample fuel for storm development.

title: Atlantic front forming into tropical storm headed toward U . S . Virgin Islands
message:

It would be the fifth named storm of the Atlantic hurricane season so far, as indicated by its temporary name.

title: Virginia Task Force 2 returns home after Hurricane Debby hazard response trip
message:
VIRGINIA BEACH, Va — Virginia Beach welcomed home a convoy of Urban Search and Rescue Virginia Task Force 2 members Sunday evening.
They had been helping in South Carolina as the remnants of Hurricane Debby moved through the area.
This time, the task force was in South Carolina to help as a 911 asset and with damage assessment.
"That's actually where the urban search and rescue program got its start is from earthquakes.
It is part of FEMA's Urban Search Rescue team and Virginia Task Force 2 is based in Virginia Beach.

The potential cyclone was gaining strength rapidly enough that the center said it would most likely be a named tropical storm by the end of Monday.

title: Debby aftermath leaves thousands in the dark ; threatens more flooding in the Carolinas
message:
With the ground already saturated from Debby, the National Weather Service said localized downpours could result in additional flash flooding throughout the coastal Carolinas.
“Right now, it’s thundering, sprinkling and pretty dark so I’d say it’s going to start raining hard here pretty soon,” she said.
Even in drier areas, more than 35,000 homes and businesses in Ohio, New York, Pennsylvania and Vermont still had no electricity as of Sunday afternoon, according to the tracking website PowerOutage.us.
Debby’s last day and night over the U.S. inundated parts of New York, Pennsylvania and New England with rain and flash flooding on Friday, prompting evacuations and rescues.
Officials announced plans to distribute water bottles and clean-up kits to residents impacted by flash flooding on Sunday and Monday.

title: Emergency assistance to be available for homeowners impacted by storms
message:
ALLEGANY COUNTY, N.Y. (WKBW — Governor Kathy Hochul announced emergency assistance will be made available to help homeowners impacted by the remnants of Hurricane Debby.
As the storm moved north, areas across New York and northern Pennsylvania were hit hard by heavy rain, flooding and tornadoes.
New York Homes and Community Renewal is launching an emergency repair program for homeowners in Allegany, Delaware, Franklin, Steuben, and St. Lawrence Counties impacted by the storm.
Under this program, homeowners in those counties will be eligible for grants of $50,000 to fund qualifying repairs to damage caused by the storm that are not covered by insurance.
Staff from the New York State Department of Financial Services will also be deployed to impacted communities to support residents and businesses with financial services questions.

title: Debby aftermath leaves thousands without power , threatens more floods : NPR
message:
Debby left thousands in the dark, and threats of more floodingtoggle caption Craig Ruttle/APPHILADELPHIA — The weather system previously known as Hurricane Debby was not quite done with parts of the U.S. Sunday as flood warnings remained in effect in North Carolina and thousands were without power in New York, Ohio and Pennsylvania.
With the ground already saturated from Debby, the National Weather Service said localized downpours could result in additional flash flooding throughout the coastal Carolinas.
Even in drier areas, more than 35,000 homes and businesses in Ohio, New York, Pennsylvania and Vermont still had no electricity as of Sunday afternoon, according to the tracking website PowerOutage.us.
Debby’s last day and night over the U.S. inundated parts of New York, Pennsylvania and New England with rain and flash flooding on Friday, prompting evacuations and rescues.
Officials announced plans to distribute water bottles and clean-up kits to residents impacted by flash flooding on Sunday and Monday.

title: Potential Tropical Cyclone 5 nears Leeward Islands , conditions favorable for further development
message:
ORLANDO, Fla. – As of 5 p.m. Sunday the National Hurricane Center has designated the tropical wave as Potential Tropical Cyclone 5 in the Atlantic.
Potential Tropical Cyclone 5 (Copyright 2024 The Associated Press.
This disturbance is expected to become a tropical storm, gaining the name Ernesto before reaching the Leeward Islands early Tuesday morning.
Tropical Storm Watches are in effect for the Leeward Islands.

Area resident Stephanie Waters said parts of sheds, branches and uprooted trees were among the debris that slammed into the span.
PPL reported 9,139 customers without power in Pennsylvania while First Energy reported 4,760 outages in the commonwealth.
Debby was downgraded to a tropical depression late Thursday afternoon and was a post-tropical cyclone on Friday, the National Hurricane Center said.

title: Ships in the Gulf of Mexico escaped Hurricane Debby in good time . It not always so easy
message:
Another company that works with the shipping industry, ZeroNorth, goes further.
These bigger storms are, ironically, forcing shipping industry emissions higher still, and further from their climate targets.
He points out that the shipping industry as a whole produces around one billion tonnes of CO2e annually.
Meyer argues that the shipping industry should make more use of route optimisation to reduce emissions where possible.
According to a 2000 study from the International Maritime Organization, route optimisation could shave 2-4% from shipping industry emissions, on average.

title: Light earthquake 4 . 4 mag , 103 km NNW of Lae , Papua New Guinea
message:
A light earthquake magnitude 4.4 (ml/mb) has occurred on Wednesday, 103 km NNW of Lae, Papua New Guinea (64 miles).
Exact location of earthquake, 146.7853° East, -5.8094° South, depth 9.357 km.
Event ids that are associated to the earthquake: us6000ngpn.
The epicenter of the earthquake was roughly 9.357 km (6 miles) below the earth’s surface.

title: Potential Tropical System # 5 headed toward the Atlantic
message:
Credit: The Weather AuthorityThe Weather Authority is tracking Potential Tropical System #5 as it approaches the Atlantic.
According to the Monday National Hurricane Center 5 a.m. advisory, the potential tropical system is expected to be upgraded to a hurricane by mid-week.
The tropical system is designated as such because it has no closed circulation; therefore, It cannot be considered a tropical depression but is expected to impact land as a tropical storm.
The system is expected to be well east of Florida but will bring greater surf and rip currents to the state.
If the storm is upgraded to a hurricane, It will be Hurricane Ernesto.

title: Light earthquake : M4 quake has struck near Goroka in Papua New Guinea
message:
A light earthquake with magnitude 4 (ml/mb) was detected on Wednesday, 21 kilometers (13 miles) from Goroka in Papua New Guinea.
The earthquake occurred at a depth of 109.029 km (68 miles) below the earth’s surface.
Epicenter of the earthquake was 21 km (13 miles) from Goroka (c. 18 500 pop), 65 km (40 miles) from Kundiawa (c. 9 400 pop), 39 km (24 miles) from Kainantu (c. 8 500 pop).
Nearby country/countries that might be effected, Papua New Guinea (c. 6 065 000 pop).
Read more about the earthquake, Distances, Seismometer information, Date-Time, Parameters, Location and details about this quake, that has struck: 21 km SE of Goroka, Papua New Guinea.

title: Light earthquake , 4 . 5 mag has occurred near Ternate in Indonesia
message:
A light earthquake with magnitude 4.5 (ml/mb) was reported 81 kilometers (50 miles) from Ternate in Indonesia on Monday.
Id of earthquake: us6000njjk.
The earthquake was roughly at a depth of 140.533 km (87 miles).
Epicenter of the event was 82 km (51 miles) from Ternate (c. 101 700 pop), 92 km (57 miles) from Sofifi (c. 36 200 pop), 84 km (52 miles) from Tobelo (c. 10 000 pop).
Read more about the earthquake, Seismometer information, Distances, Parameters, Date-Time, Location and details about this quake, that has occurred near: 81 km N of Ternate, Indonesia.

title: Hot week ahead and full details on Potential Cyclone Five
message:
Tomorrow and for the rest of the week, we'll be seeing highs in the upper 90s.
Breyanna Lewis/KATCBreyanna Lewis/KATCInvest 98L has now developed into Potential Tropical Cyclone Five, or soon-to-be Tropical Storm Ernesto.
Breyanna Lewis/KATCForecasts suggest that it reaches tropical storm status tomorrow and potentially become a Category 1 hurricane by Wednesday.
Breyanna Lewis/KATCTropical storm watches are already in place for the Leeward Islands as PTC 5 approaches on Tuesday.
Puerto Rico, the British Virgin Islands, and the U.S. Virgin Islands are likely to have watches issued soon.

title: Potential tropical cyclone five emerges in tropical Atlantic : Soon - to - be Ernesto
message:
As of the Sunday at 5 p.m. advisory from the National Hurricane Center, the disturbance has been designated Potential Tropical Cyclone Five.
With the 11 p.m. Sunday advisory, soon-to-be Ernesto packs maximum sustained winds up to 30 miles per hour and a minimum central pressure of 1009 millibars.
A tropical storm is possible as early as Monday as it nears the Leeward Islands.
Before Monday, the system is battling some wind shear, however, the wind shear is forecast to decrease as the system moves west/northwesterly.
The current forecast track shows the storm likely turning north, towards Bermuda and otherwise open Atlantic ocean.

title: Mild drop in temperatures with rain chances by mid - week
message:
COLUMBIA, SC (WACH) -- Sunday has been pleasant with a few rounds of afternoon showers and isolated storms.
This week, the temperature will drop earlier, with a constant threat of afternoon showers and thunderstorms.
Monday's forecast area is predicted to have little showers and thunderstorms, with the likelihood of showers and thunderstorms increasing on Tuesday.
TROPICAL UPDATE:The disturbance will become a tropical storm before reaching the Leeward Islands, in the Caribbean Sea.
The National Hurricane Center predicts tropical storm conditions could begin on Tuesday for some islands.

title: Hurricane Charley 20 years later : Historic front pages from before , after storm
message:
Hurricane Charley 20 years later: Historic front pages from before, after stormStop the presses!
When Hurricane Charley slammed the Southwest Florida coast two decades ago, on Aug. 13, 2004, reporters, photographers and editors working for The News-Press were challenged with covering a story like none they had covered before.
The New-Press swarmed the region covering the aftermath with impactful Page 1A presentations for days after the historic storm.
Here's a look back at some of those pages that started as Charley made its well-known turn to the right and put Southwest Florida in its sites.
Hurricane Charley: Gallery of historic front pages from 20 years agoThis article originally appeared on Fort Myers News-Press: What part of Florida did Hurricane Charley hit the worst?

title: First Alert Weather : Tropical Storm Watches issued for Caribbean islands , Florida looking good this time
message:
SARASOTA, Fla. (WWSB) - Over the weekend a system we have been watching has organized and is expected to become a significant Tropical Storm and possibly a hurricane this week.
Watches are up in the Leeward Islands and more watches and/or warnings are likely as we go through today and tomorrow.
As the storm moves closer to the Virgin Islands and Puerto Rico it is expected to begin to turn to a more northerly direction.
This will shift the winds to the north or northeast and dive in some much drier air by the weekend.
This will lower weekend rain chances.

title: UK braced for  hottest day of the year  as scorching weather nears | united kingdom News
message:
People will flock to the beaches today to enjoy the hottest day of the year (Picture: Matt Keeble/Shutterstock)London and the south are hotting up today as UK weather could record its highest temperature of the year as the mercury hits highs of 34°C.
Hot and humid temperatures are the theme of the day – as London experiences highs of 33°C, while Cambridge could top that at 34°C.
The Midlands, Lincolnshire, East Anglia and south east England will be hot and humid with temperatures reaching 30°C or more.
What’s the UK Weather for today?
A yellow weather warning for thunderstorms has been issued for parts of the north of England, Scotland and Northern Ireland.

title: Tracking the tropics , and following rain and heat locally
message:
Ok, so today is much of the same in the way of highs in the 90′s, “feels like temps” in the triple digits (reaching 112 in some spots!
), and a few showers and pop-up storms are in the forecast.
As the kids go back to school, make sure they pack an umbrella so the bus ride home stays dry!
:)Tropics wise, I am tracking Potential Tropical Cyclone 5, and per the National Hurricane Center, this storm is set to likely become a Tropical Storm before it reaches the Leeward Islands.
This storm is set currently to turn and stay out in the Atlantic.

title: Storm dumps heavy rainfall on northern Japan , sending some people to shelters
message:
By MARI YAMAGUCHIA slow-moving storm has been dumping intense rains on northern Japan, swelling rivers, sending residents to shelters and disrupting traffic during a Japanese Buddhist holiday week.
The storm was once Typhoon Maria but has weakened, with winds now blowing up to 72 kph.
It made landfall near Ofunato City in Iwate Prefecture Monday morning and was expected to cut across the Tohoku region as it moved northwest at 20 kph, according to the Japan Meteorological Agency.
Iwate prefecture said about 2,000 people actually took shelter early Monday.
This storm is the first to make landfall in the Tohoku region since the 2016 typhoon.

title: Crews to make final pass for Beryl - related storm debris in Pasadena Monday
message:
PASADENA, Texas – The City of Pasadena says crews will begin making their final passes to collect storm debris left over from Hurricane Beryl on Monday.
Recommended VideosThe city reminds people to place all storm-related debris at the curb by 5 a.m. Monday.
PASADENA REMINDER: Beryl storm debris collection crews will begin their final routes on 8/12/24.
Please place all storm-related debris at the curb no later than 5AM on Monday, 8/12/24.
— City of Pasadena TX #pasadenatxgov (@pasadenatxgov) August 11, 2024Freshly cut yard waste and non-Beryl debris will not be collected during the passes.

title: Storm dumps intense rainfall on northern Japan , sending some people to shelters
message:
Storm dumps intense rainfall on northern Japan, sending some people to sheltersTOKYO (AP) — A slow-moving storm has been dumping intense rains on northern Japan, swelling rivers, sending residents to shelters and disrupting traffic during a Japanese Buddhist holiday week.
The storm was once Typhoon Maria but has weakened, with winds now blowing up to 72 kph (45 mph).
Iwate prefecture said about 2,000 people actually took shelter early Monday.
Prime Minister Fumio Kishida vowed that the government would quickly provide information and support to residents in the affected areas.
This storm is the first to make landfall in the Tohoku region since the 2016 typhoon.

title: Storm dumps intense rainfall on northern Japan , sending some people to shelters
message:
A slow-moving storm is dumping intense rainfall on northern Japan, causing rivers to swell and sending some residents to sheltersTOKYO -- A slow-moving storm has been dumping intense rains on northern Japan, swelling rivers, sending residents to shelters and disrupting traffic during a Japanese Buddhist holiday week.
The storm was once Typhoon Maria but has weakened, with winds now blowing up to 72 kph (45 mph).
Iwate prefecture said about 2,000 people actually took shelter early Monday.
This storm is the first to make landfall in the Tohoku region since the 2016 typhoon.
The storm was affecting travel during the Obon holiday period in which people commemorate their ancestors.

title: Severe tropical storm makes landfall in Japan
message:
SEVERE Tropical Storm Maria on Monday made landfall in northern Japan, having dumped more than two months worth of rain in the previous 24 hours and forcing the cancellation of dozens of flights.
Maria, which was categorised as a “severe tropical storm”, a level below typhoon, made landfall around 8.30 am (2330 GMT Sunday) near Ofunato city in Iwate prefecture, the Japan Meteorological Agency said.
Japan Airlines said it cancelled 78 domestic flights, affecting 7,039 passengers.
Some regional train services suspended their services, although the bullet train system continued its normal operations.
The storm was expected to cross Japan and head out to the Sea of Japan by Monday evening.

title: POTENTIALLY TROPICAL STORM # 5
message:
SARASOTA, Fla. (WWSB) - A disturbance east of the Lesser Antilles is expected to become the fifth tropical storm of the season before it reaches the island chain.
A tropical storm watch has been issued for the Leeward Islands.
Tropical storm watches or warnings will likely be issued tonight or Monday for Puerto Rico, and the British and U.S. Virgin Islands.
The storms is expected to take a turn to the north after passing over Puerto Rico, and head toward Bermuda as a category 2 hurricane.
At this point the models are not showing impacts to the United States, aside from possibly increasing the tropical moisture in the atmosphere.

title: Potential tropical cyclone not a threat to Bermuda
message:
Forecast for Potential Tropical Cyclone Five as of August 11 at 6pm (Photograph from the Bermuda Weather Service)A potential tropical cyclone was being monitored but was not considered a threat to Bermuda within the next three to five days as it moved to the northern Atlantic Ocean.
Potential Tropical Cyclone Five’s closest point of approach within the next 72 hours was predicted to be about 832 miles south of Bermuda on Wednesday at about 6pm.
The Bermuda Weather Service warned that despite the prediction, the storm may come closer after that.
Potential Tropical Cyclone Five was approximately 1,671 miles southeast of Bermuda at 6pm today and was moving in a west-northwest direction at about 21mph.
The storm can be tracked on the Bermuda Weather Service’s website.

title: Nice  sunny weather in Boston forecast ,  dangerous rip current may threaten towards weekend
message:
“It’s looking like a pretty nice week, said National Weather Service meteorologist Kevin Pederson.
The region will likely be cooled by calm winds throughout the week, according to NWS forecasts.
“But other than that, it should be nice weather for the work week ahead,” Pederson said.
The Southeast Atlantic coast may experience “rough surf and dangerous rip currents” towards the end of the week, DaSilva said.
“Anyone heading to East coast beaches this week needs to be aware and know the warning signs.

title: Residents flee as Greece wildfires rage despite  superhuman  efforts
message:
“Greece ordered fresh evacuations near Athens on Monday (August 12, 2024) as wildfires spread despite “superhuman” efforts to contain the flames,” firefighters said.
At least five more communities were told to flee by civil protection authorities on Monday, after hundreds of people evacuated on August 11, 2024, from at least eight villages.
"Civil protection forces battled hard throughout the night, but despite superhuman efforts, the fire evolved rapidly," fire brigade spokesman Vassilis Vathrakogiannis said.
Temperatures are forecast to peak at 39 degrees Celsius (102 degrees Fahrenheit) in Greece on August 11, 2024, with wind gusts of up to 50 km (31 miles) per hour.
But the force was battling seven more in the high summer heat, the fire brigade spokesman said on Sunday (August 11, 2024.)

title: Severe Tropical Storm Maria makes landfall in Japan
message:
TOKYO, Aug 12, 2024 (BSS/AFP) - Severe Tropical Storm Maria on Monday made landfall in northern Japan, having dumped more than two months worth of rain in the previous 24 hours and forcing the cancellation of dozens of flights.
Maria, which was categorised as a "severe tropical storm", a level below typhoon, made landfall around 8:30 am (2330 GMT Sunday) near Ofunato city in Iwate prefecture, the Japan Meteorological Agency said.
Maria was bringing gusts of up to 126 kilometres (78 miles) per hour and moving northwest at 15 kilometres per hour, the agency said.
Some regional train services suspended their services, although the bullet train system continued its normal operations.
The storm was expected to cross Japan and head out to the Sea of Japan by Monday evening.

message:

title: Residents Flee As Greece Wildfires Rage Despite  Superhuman  Efforts
message:
(MENAFN- The Peninsula) AFPAthens: Greece ordered fresh evacuations near Athens on Monday as wildfires spread despite "superhuman" efforts to contain the flames, firefighters said.
"Civil protection forces battled hard throughout the night, but despite superhuman efforts, the fire evolved rapidly," fire brigade spokesman Vassilis Vathrakogiannis said.
Volunteers put on protective gear as they sit atop a pickup truck during a wildfire in Varnavas, north of Athens, on August 11, 2024.
A house burns during a wildfire in Varnavas, north of Athens, on August 11, 2024.
A wildfire burns vegetation along a road during a wildfire in Varnavas, north of Athens, on August 11, 2024.

title: Forest Service works to stabilize Alexander Mountain Fire burn scar with response team
message:
DENVER (KDVR) — The Alexander Mountain Fire has burned over 9,600 acres and is still not 100% contained, according to the U.S. Forest Service Roosevelt National Forest, but a team has been organized to complete a Burned Area Emergency Response assessment.
The goal is to stabilize the burned area as quickly and effectively as possible.
(Jason Sieg/USDA Forest Service via AP)A couple watches the Alexander Mountain and Stone Canyon fire burn from Lac Amora Open Space in Broomfield.
(Heather Willard, KDVR)The Alexander Mountain Fire seen from Equalizer Lake in Loveland on July 29, 2024.
Douglas County’s Helitack Team responds to the Alexander Mountain Fire in Larimer County on July 30, 2024.

title: UK insurers pay out record claims as weather - related claims surge , industry body says
message:
UK insurers pay out record claims as weather-related claims surge, industry body saysreuters_tickers2 minutes(Reuters) – Insurers paid out a record-high 1.4 billion pounds ($1.78 billion) in claims in the UK during the second quarter, primarily due to weather-related catastrophes such as fires and flooding, the Association of British Insurers said on Monday.
Homeowners and businesses alike are struggling with damages from storms, heavy rain, and frozen pipes.
Claims for damages to homes reached £144 million in the period, marking the fifth consecutive quarter weather-related claims have exceeded £100 million, the ABI reported.
Increased flooding in Britain from overflowing rivers and blocked drains is causing insurers to pull back from offering coverage, particularly for commercial properties and residential landlords, according to industry representatives.
The industry body said a much-needed reform to the planning system, with a focus on prevention measures, is essential to better fortify the country against climate change.

title: Hochul visits Canisteo after flooding , tells community  You will not be forgotten
message:
CANISTEO, N.Y. (WETM) — Governor Kathy Hochul visited Canisteo on Sunday afternoon to address the community two days after flooding caused severe damage in the area.
How can Steuben County residents impacted by flooding get help?
In addition to helping flood victims get money from insurance companies, New York State will be giving homeowners money to address damages.
Hochul stressed that Steuben County’s elected officials care about their community and are united in sharing their resources and rebuilding.
Steuben County Chair Kelly Fitzpatrick and Senator Tom O’Mara were among the local officials standing alongside Hochul in Canisteo.

title: From farm to table : How extreme weather affects prices along the food supply chain
message:
Extreme weather events like fires, floods, heat waves and droughts pose an increasing risk to Canada’s food supply chain, putting pressure on prices all the way to the grocery store shelf, say experts.
Extreme weather events like fires, floods, heat waves and droughts pose an increasing risk to Canada’s food supply chain, putting pressure on prices all the way to the grocery store shelf, say experts.
“For example, you might have damaged infrastructure from floods that changes transportation routes and the ability to move those products along the food supply chain.”Shortages caused by extreme weather can also drive food prices higher if supply isn’t able to meet demand, she said.
Those practices can’t protect crops from the most extreme weather, he said, but they do help in other years.
A disruption on one part of the supply chain can create a “domino effect,” he said.

title: Colleton County zoo says its animals are safe
message:
COTTAGEVILLE, S.C. (WCSC) - A popular zoo in Colleton County posted on social media Sunday that all of its animals are safe from floodwaters caused by Tropical Storm Debby.
In a post on social media, the Bee City Zoo & Honey Bee Farm said workers were able to prepare for the rainfall Debby brought and the flooding that soon followed.
The post stated zoo officials were able to help neighbors after they evacuated their animals.
“We are so blessed to have so many good friends in the Zoo industry and all the way around,” the post stated.
Like most... Posted by Bee City on Sunday, August 11, 2024Bee City is family-owned and operated and began over 30 years ago, its website states.

title: 4 Lowcountry school districts announce schedule changes amid continued flooding
message:
Berkeley County School DistrictBerkeley County students will return to school later than originally planned, district leaders announced Saturday.
Two other Lowcountry school districts announced delayed starts to the new school year in the aftermath of Tropical Storm Debby.
Dorchester County School District 4Dorchester District 4 posted on its Facebook page that their students will now start school on Wednesday.
The Colleton County School District said it would make the switch because of the possibility of additional rain and river cresting.
Meanwhile, three other Lowcountry school districts in Berkeley and Dorchester Counties announced delays for the first day of school for their students.

title: List of donation sites near you
message:
Over the past week WTOC has continued coverage of families and business affected by rising floodwaters.
As a result of flooding many communities have begun setting up donation centers.
They said the list of items needed may change over the next few days.
The city of Richmond Hill is also set up a donation center.
For the city of Savannah, individuals that want to donate items can go to the Salvation Army at 3100 Montgomery St.

title: Emergency alerts issued as Tropical Storm Maria moves over Tohoku
message:
Tropical Storm Maria moved over the Tohoku region on Monday, leading to emergency warnings in some areas and concerns about swelling rivers and landslides.
A satellite image shows Tropical Storm Maria over the Tohoku region on Monday morning | Meteorological AgencyThe storm was also impacting public transportation as many are traveling for the Bon holiday period.
Maria is just the third tropical storm to make landfall on Tohoku’s Pacific coast since records began, according to the Meteorological Agency.
Tropical Storm Son-tinh, well away from land in the Pacific, is forecast to weaken into a tropical depression by Wednesday as it approaches eastern Hokkaido.
A tropical depression south of the archipelago, however, is forecast to strengthen into a tropical storm by Tuesday, possibly gaining strength further as it nears eastern Japan by the weekend.

title: Roundup : Raging wildfire forces evacuation of more than 30 , 000 residents in Greece
message:
You are here:视频播放位置 下载安装Flash播放器ATHENS, Aug. 11 (Xinhua) -- Greek authorities on Sunday ordered the evacuation of more than 30,000 residents of Marathon town, northeastern Attica region, due to a fast-moving wildfire outside Athens fuelled by hot and windy weather.
Eight people were transferred to hospitals with mainly respiratory problems, according to the latest information provided by health ministry officials.
The fire broke out around 3 p.m. local time (1200 GMT) Sunday in Varnavas, around 35 km from Athens.
Over the past 24 hours, firefighting forces have responded to 40 wildfires across Greece, the spokesperson said.
Greece experiences numerous wildfires each summer in connection to heatwaves and arson.

title: Greece wildfires force thousands to flee historic site and popular tourist towns
message:

Kyriakos Mitsotakis, the prime minister, cut short his holiday and returned to Athens on Sunday to oversee the emergency response.
Hospitals in Athens remained on high alert as a thick cloud of brown smoke blanketed parts of the city.
Greece has witnessed hundreds of fires this summer, which brought the hottest June and July on record to the country.

title: Sudan Displaced Millions Face Escalating Hardship Amid War and Floods
message:
Displaced multiple timesMs. Sarrado informed the press that the displaced have been forced to move three or four times since the start of the conflict.
According to the UN Children's Fund (UNICEF), 18 million children in Sudan are out of schools.
Listen to the full interview belowClose Sign up for free AllAfrica Newsletters Get the latest in African news delivered straight to your inbox Top Headlines International Organisations Sudan Refugees By submitting above, you agree to our privacy policy.
Decimated livelihoodsThe conflict in Sudan has decimated crops and livelihoods, with the climate crisis further endangering the displaced population.
Considering the escalating crisis, UNHCR launched a regional floods appeal for nearly $40 million to assist and protect 5.6 million refugees, returnees, internally displaced persons (IDPs) and local communities across East Africa, including in Sudan.

title: Typhoon Maria Wreaks Havoc In Japan
message:
(MENAFN- IANS) Tokyo, Aug 12 (IANS) Typhoon Maria on Monday made landfall in the northeast Japanese prefecture of Iwate, unleashing record-breaking rainfall and severe disruptions across the Tohoku region.
Japan Airlines and All Nippon Airways have cancelled over 80 flights, mainly connecting Tohoku with Tokyo and Osaka.
East Japan Railway Company reports potential delays on the Tohoku, Yamagata, and Akita Shinkansen lines, and has suspended operations on some local lines.
Road travel is also affected, with sections of the Tohoku and Joban Expressways likely to be closed due to the ongoing downpour.
With more rainfall expected, especially along the coast of the Sea of Japan, landslide risks are escalating in Iwate and surrounding areas, according to the JMA.

title: Police find body of missing man in his 80s who was swept up in Quebec river
message:
The Canadian PressQuebec provincial police say they have found the body of a man in his 80s who went missing late on Friday after a roadway collapsed and he was swept into the Batiscan River in the province's Mauricie region.
Police say the man was discovered in the municipality of Lac-aux-Sables on Sunday morning and was pronounced dead at the scene.
The man went missing on the day that post-tropical storm Debby drenched Southern Quebec, washing out roads, flooding basements and knocking out power across the province.
Drones and a helicopter were deployed to assist in the search.
Police say they are investigating in collaboration with the coroner’s office to determine what led to the death.

title: Climate crisis helped drive payouts to seven - year high , say insurers
message:
Britain’s largest insurance firms have warned that the climate crisis has contributed to driving up insurance payouts to the highest level in seven years, after a sharp rise in damage to households and businesses from weather events.
For more information see our Privacy Policy .
We use Google reCaptcha to protect our website and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.
after newsletter promotionClark said: “Home insurance continues to play a vital role in supporting customers when the worst happens.
“Despite rising cost pressures, insurers remain committed to doing everything they can to offer competitively priced cover and help their customers during a claim.”

title: Potential tropical cyclone five emerges in tropical Atlantic : Soon - to - be Ernesto
message:
As of the Sunday at 5 p.m. advisory from the National Hurricane Center, the disturbance has been designated Potential Tropical Cyclone Five.
With the 11 p.m. Sunday advisory, soon-to-be Ernesto packs maximum sustained winds up to 30 miles per hour and a minimum central pressure of 1009 millibars.
A tropical storm is possible as early as Monday as it nears the Leeward Islands.
Before Monday, the system is battling some wind shear, however, the wind shear is forecast to decrease as the system moves west/northwesterly.
The current forecast track shows the storm likely turning north, towards Bermuda and otherwise open Atlantic ocean.
